comet.graphÔÉÅ

comet.graph.avg_clustering_onella(W: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Average clustering coefficient as described by Onnela et al. (2005) and as implemented in https://kk1995.github.io/BauerLab/BauerLab/MATLAB/lib/+mouse/+graph/smallWorldPropensity.html

Parameters:

W (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì binary or weighted, undirected connection matrix

Returns:

C ‚Äì average clustering coefficient

Return type:

float

References

Onnela, J. P., Saram√§ki, J., Kert√©sz, J., & Kaski, K. (2005). Intensity and coherence of motifs in weighted complex networks. Physical Review E, 71(6), 065103. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.71.065103

comet.graph.avg_shortest_path(G: ndarray, include_diagonal: bool = False, include_infinite: bool = False) → float[source]ÔÉÅ

Average shortest path length calculated from a connection length matrix.

For binary matrices the connection length matrix is identical to the connectiivty matrix, for weighted connectivity matrices it can be obtained though e.g. graph.invert().

Parameters:

G (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected connection matrix (binary or weighted)

Returns:

D ‚Äì average shortest path length

Return type:

float

comet.graph.backbone_wu(CIJ: ndarray, avgdeg: int = 0, verbose: bool = False) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the backbone_wu() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The network backbone contains the dominant connections in the network and may be used to aid network visualization. This function computes the backbone of a given weighted and undirected connection matrix CIJ, using a minimum-spanning-tree based algorithm.

Parameters:

  • CIJ (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì weighted undirected connection matrix

  • avgdeg (float) ‚Äì desired average degree of backbone

  • verbose (bool) ‚Äì print out edges whilst building spanning tree. Default False.

Returns:

  • CIJtree (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì connection matrix of the minimum spanning tree of CIJ

  • CIJclus (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì connection matrix of the minimum spanning tree plus strongest connections up to some average degree ‚Äòavgdeg‚Äô. Identical to CIJtree if the degree requirement is already met.

Notes

Nodes with zero strength are discarded.

CIJclus will have a total average degree exactly equal to

(or very close to) ‚Äòavgdeg‚Äô.

‚Äòavgdeg‚Äô backfill is handled slightly differently than in Hagmann et al. (2008)

comet.graph.betweenness(G: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the betweenness_*() functions of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

Node betweenness centrality is the fraction of all shortest paths in the network that contain a given node. Nodes with high values of betweenness centrality participate in a large number of shortest paths.

Parameters:

G (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì binary/weighted directed/undirected connection matrix

Returns:

BC ‚Äì node betweenness centrality vector

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

Notes

Binary: Betweenness centrality may be normalised to the range [0,1] as BC/[(N-1)(N-2)], where N is the number of nodes in the network.

Weighted: The input matrix must be a connection-length matrix, typically obtained via a mapping from weight to length. For instance, in a weighted correlation network higher correlations are more naturally interpreted as shorter distances and the input matrix should consequently be some inverse of the connectivity matrix. Betweenness centrality may be normalised to the range [0,1] as BC/[(N-1)(N-2)], where N is the number of nodes in the network.

comet.graph.binarise(W: ndarray, copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Binarise connectivity/adjacency matrix

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì binarised adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.clustering_coef(W: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the clustering_coef_*() functions of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The binary clustering coefficient is the fraction of triangles around a node (equiv. the fraction of nodes neighbors that are neighbors of each other).

The weighted clustering coefficient is the average ‚Äúintensity‚Äù of triangles around a node.

Parameters:

W (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì weighted undirected connection matrix

Returns:

C ‚Äì clustering coefficient vector

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

comet.graph.degrees_und(CIJ: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the degrees_und() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

Node degree is the number of links connected to the node.

Parameters:

CIJ (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected binary/weighted connection matrix

Returns:

deg ‚Äì node degree

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

Notes

Weight information is discarded.

comet.graph.density_und(CIJ: ndarray) → tuple[float, int, int][source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the density_und() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

Density is the fraction of present connections to possible connections.

Parameters:

CIJ (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì directed weighted/binary connection matrix

Returns:

  • kden (float) ‚Äì density

  • N (int) ‚Äì number of vertices

  • k (int) ‚Äì number of edges

Notes

Assumes CIJ is directed and has no self-connections. Weight information is discarded.

comet.graph.distance_bin(G: ndarray, inv: bool = False) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Distance matrix calculation for binary networks with significantly improved performance due to numba compilation.

Parameters:

G (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì undireted weighted adjacency/connectivity matrix

Returns:

D ‚Äì (inverse) distance matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

Notes

Algorithm: Matrix multiplication to find paths, faster than original Dijkstra‚Äôs algorithm

comet.graph.distance_wei(G: ndarray, inv: bool = False) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

(Inverse) distance matrix for weighted networks with significantly improved performance due to numba compilation.

Parameters:

  • G (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì undireted weighted adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • inv (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, the element wise inverse of the distance matrux is returned. Default is True

Returns:

D ‚Äì (inverse) distance matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

Notes

Algorithm: Modified Dijkstra‚Äôs algorithm

comet.graph.efficiency(G: ndarray, local: bool = False) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Efficiency for binary and weighted networks (global and local)

Optimized version of the bctpy implelementation by Roan LaPlante (https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy)

Global efficiency is the average of inverse shortest path length, and is inversely related to the characteristic path length. Local efficiency is the global efficiency computed on the neighborhood of the node, and is related to the clustering coefficient.

Parameters:

  • Gw (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix (binary or weighted, directed or undirected)

  • local (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, local efficiency is computed. Default is False (global efficiency)

Returns:

  • E (global) (float) ‚Äì global efficiency, if local is False

  • E (local) (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì local efficiency, if local is True

References

Latora, V., & Marchiori, M. (2001). Efficient behavior of small-world networks. Physical review letters, 87(19), 198701. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.87.198701

Onnela, J. P., Saram√§ki, J., Kert√©sz, J., & Kaski, K. (2004). Intensity and coherence of motifs in weighted c omplex networks. Physical Review E, 71(6), 065103. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.71.065103

Fagiolo, G. (2007). Clustering in complex directed networks. Physical Review E, 76(2), 026107. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.76.026107

Rubinov, M., & Sporns, O. (2010). Complex network measures of brain connectivity: uses and interpretations. Neuroimage, 52(3), 1059-1069. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2009.10.003

Wang, Y., Ghumare, E., Vandenberghe, R., & Dupont, P. (2017). Comparison of different generalizations of clustering coefficient and local efficiency for weighted undirected graphs. Neural computation, 29(2), 313-331. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1162/NECO_a_00914

comet.graph.eigenvector_centrality_und(CIJ: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the eigenvector_centrality_*() functions of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

Eigenector centrality is a self-referential measure of centrality: nodes have high eigenvector centrality if they connect to other nodes that have high eigenvector centrality. The eigenvector centrality of node i is equivalent to the ith element in the eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix.

Parameters:

CIJ (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì Binary/weighted undirected adjacency matrix

Returns:

v ‚Äì Eigenvector associated with the largest eigenvalue of the matrix

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

comet.graph.gateway_coef_sign(W: ndarray, ci: Literal['louvain'] = 'louvain', centrality_type: Literal['degree', 'betweenness'] = 'degree') → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the gateway_coef_sign() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The gateway coefficient is a variant of participation coefficient. It is weighted by how critical the connections are to intermodular connectivity (e.g. if a node is the only connection between its module and another module, it will have a higher gateway coefficient, unlike participation coefficient).

Parameters:

  • W (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected signed connection matrix

  • ci (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì community affiliation vector

  • centrality_type (enum) ‚Äì ‚Äòdegree‚Äô - uses the weighted degree (i.e, node strength) ‚Äòbetweenness‚Äô - uses the betweenness centrality

Returns:

  • Gpos (N x nr_mod np.ndarray) ‚Äì gateway coefficient for positive weights

  • Gneg (N x nr_mod np.ndarray) ‚Äì gateway coefficient for negative weights

References

Vargas ER, Wahl LM, Eur Phys J B (2014) 87:1-10

comet.graph.handle_negative_weights(W: ndarray, type: Literal['absolute', 'discard'] = 'absolute', copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Handle negative weights in a connectivity/adjacency matrix

Connectivity methods can produce negative estimates, which can be handled in different ways before graph analysis.

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • type (string, optional) ‚Äì type of handling, can be absolute or discard default is absolute

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix with only positive weights

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.invert(W: ndarray, copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Invert connectivity/adjacency matrix

Element wise inversion W such that each value W[i,j] will be 1 / W[i,j] (internode strengths internode distances)

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì element wise inverted adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.logtransform(W: ndarray, epsilon: float = 1e-10, copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Log transform of connectivity/adjacency matrix

Element wise log transform of W such that each value W[i,j] will be -log(W[i,j]

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • epsilon (float, optional) ‚Äì clipping value for numeric stability, default is 1e-10

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì element wise log transformed adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.matching_ind_und(G: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Matching index for undirected networks

Based on the MATLAB implementation by Stuart Oldham: https://github.com/StuartJO/FasterMatchingIndex

Matching index is a measure of similarity between two nodes‚Äô connectivity profiles (excluding their mutual connection, should it exist). Weighted matrices will be binarised.

Parameters:

W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected adjacency/connectivity matrix, will be binarised

Returns:

M ‚Äì matching index matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

References

Oldham, S., Fulcher, B. D., Aquino, K., Arnatkeviƒçi≈´tƒó, A., Paquola, C., Shishegar, R., & Fornito, A. (2022). Modeling spatial, developmental, physiological, and topological constraints on human brain connectivity. Science advances, 8(22), eabm6127. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.abm6127

Betzel, R. F., Avena-Koenigsberger, A., Go√±i, J., He, Y., De Reus, M. A., Griffa, A., ‚Ä¶ & Sporns, O. (2016). Generative models of the human connectome. Neuroimage, 124, 1054-1064. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2015.09.041

Notes

Important note: As of Jan 2024 there is a bug in the bctpy version of this function (ncon2 = c1 * CIJ should instead be ncon2 = CIJ * use)

This bug is irrelevant here due to the opimized implementation.

comet.graph.pagerank_centrality(A: ndarray, d: float = 0.85, falff: float = None) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the pagerank_centrality() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The PageRank centrality is a variant of eigenvector centrality. This function computes the PageRank centrality of each vertex in a graph.

Formally, PageRank is defined as the stationary distribution achieved by instantiating a Markov chain on a graph. The PageRank centrality of a given vertex, then, is proportional to the number of steps (or amount of time) spent at that vertex as a result of such a process.

The PageRank index gets modified by the addition of a damping factor, d. In terms of a Markov chain, the damping factor specifies the fraction of the time that a random walker will transition to one of its current state‚Äôs neighbors. The remaining fraction of the time the walker is restarted at a random vertex. A common value for the damping factor is d = 0.85.

Parameters:

  • A (NxN np.narray) ‚Äì adjacency matrix

  • d (float) ‚Äì damping factor (see description)

  • falff (Nx1 np.ndarray | None) ‚Äì Initial page rank probability, non-negative values. Default value is None. If not specified, a naive bayesian prior is used.

Returns:

r ‚Äì vectors of page rankings

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

Notes

Note: The algorithm will work well for smaller matrices (number of nodes around 1000 or less)

comet.graph.participation_coef(W: ndarray, ci: Literal['louvain'] = 'louvain', degree: Literal['undirected'] = 'undirected') → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the participation_coef functions of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The participation coefficient is a measure of diversity of intermodular connections of individual nodes.

Parameters:

  • W (NxN np.ndarray or scipy.sparse.csr_matrix) ‚Äì binary/weighted directed/undirected connection matrix

  • ci (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì community affiliation vector (just for the GUI, will always use bct.community_louvain())

  • degree (str) ‚Äì

    Flag to describe nature of graph ‚Äòundirected‚Äô: For undirected graphs

    ‚Äôin‚Äô: Uses the in-degree ‚Äòout‚Äô: Uses the out-degree

Returns:

P ‚Äì participation coefficient

Return type:

Nx1 np.ndarray

comet.graph.participation_coef_sign(W: ndarray, ci: Literal['louvain'] = 'louvain') → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

This is a wrapper function for the participation_coef_sign() function of the bctpy toolbox: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy.

The participation coefficient is a measure of diversity of intermodular connections of individual nodes.

Parameters:

  • W (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected connection matrix with positive and negative weights

  • ci (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì community affiliation vector (just for the GUI, will always use bct.community_louvain())

Returns:

  • Ppos (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì participation coefficient from positive weights

  • Pneg (Nx1 np.ndarray) ‚Äì participation coefficient from negative weights

Postprocessing of connectivity/adjacency matrix

Ensures W is symmetric, sets diagonal to diag, removes NaNs and infinities, and ensures exact binarity

Parameters:

  • diag (int, optional) ‚Äì set diagonal to this value default is 0

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì processed adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.small_world_propensity(G: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Small world propensity calculation for undirected and symmetric networks. Clustering is calculated using the approach of Onnela et al. (2005).

Based on the MATLAB and Python implementations by Eric Bridgeford, Sarah F. Muldoon, and Ryan Daniels: https://kk1995.github.io/BauerLab/BauerLab/MATLAB/lib/+mouse/+graph/smallWorldPropensity.html https://github.com/rkdan/small_world_propensity

Parameters:

F (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì undirected and symmetric adjacency/connectivity matrix

Returns:

  • SWP (float) ‚Äì small world propensity of the matrix

  • delta_C (float) ‚Äì fractional deviation from the expected culstering coefficient of a random network

  • delta_L (float) ‚Äì fractional deviation from the expected path length of a random network

  • alpha (float) ‚Äì angle between delta_C and delta_L

  • delta (float) ‚Äì scaled version of alpha in the range of [-1,1]

References

Muldoon, S., Bridgeford, E. & Bassett, D. Small-World Propensity and Weighted Brain Networks. Sci Rep 6, 22057 (2016). DOI: https://doi.org/10.1038/srep22057

Onnela, J. P., Saram√§ki, J., Kert√©sz, J., & Kaski, K. (2005). Intensity and coherence of motifs in weighted complex networks. Physical Review E, 71(6), 065103. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.71.065103

comet.graph.small_world_sigma(G: ndarray, nrand: int = 10) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Small-worldness sigma for undirected networks (binary or weighted)

Small worldness sigma is calculated as the ratio of the clustering coefficient and the characteristic path length of the real network to the average clustering coefficient and characteristic path length of the random networks.

Parameters:

  • G (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì undireted adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • nrand (int, optional) ‚Äì number of random networks to generate (and average over). Default is 10.

Returns:

sigms ‚Äì small-worldness sigma

Return type:

float

Notes

This implementation of small worldness relies on matrix operations and is drastically faster than the Networkx implementation. However, it uses a different approch for rewiring edges, so the results will differ.

It automatically detects if the input matrix is binary or weighted.

comet.graph.symmetrise(W: ndarray, copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Symmetrise connectivity/adjacency matrix

Symmetrise W such that each value W[i,j] will be W[j,i].

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì symmetrised adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

comet.graph.threshold(W: ndarray, type: Literal['density', 'absolute'] = 'density', threshold: float = None, density: float = None, copy: bool = True) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Thresholding of connectivity/adjacency matrix

Performs absolute or density-based thresholding

Parameters:

  • W (PxP np.ndarray) ‚Äì adjacency/connectivity matrix

  • type (string, optional) ‚Äì type of thresholding, can be absolute or density default is absolute

  • threshold (float, optional) ‚Äì threshold value for absolute thresholding default is None

  • density (float, optional) ‚Äì density value for density-based thresholding, has to be between 0 and 1 (keep x% of strongest connections) default is None

  • copy (bool, optional) ‚Äì if True, a copy of W is returned, otherwise W is modified in place default is True

Returns:

W ‚Äì thresholded adjacency/connectivity matrix

Return type:

PxP np.ndarray

Notes

The implemented for density based thresholding always keeps the exact same number of connections. If multiple edges have the same weight, the included edges are chosen ‚Äúrandomly‚Äù (based on their order in the sorted indices). This is identical to the behaviour in the BCT implementation.

comet.graph.transitivity_und(A: ndarray) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Transitivity for undirected networks (binary and weighted), adapted from the bctpy implementation: https://github.com/aestrivex/bctpy

Transitivity is the ratio of triangles to triplets in the network and is a classical version of the clustering coefficient.

Parameters:

A (NxN np.ndarray) ‚Äì binary undirected connection matrix

Returns:

T ‚Äì transitivity scalar

Return type:

float
